job_title: Director of Development in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Amazing faculty, deans, beautiful campus, lovely students, decent pay, and great benefit.
cons: It was defined by secrecy, backdoor discussions, an extreme case of micromanagement, lack of innovation, stubbornness to new ideas, and no desire to build genuine relationships with donors. One of the worse practices in the industry, and it made me feel uncomfortable. Build your career profile elsewhere because if you don't have something to fall back on, this is a toxic place to rely on for long-term career advancement.

review_title: University Advancement used to be great
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Retirement match up to 10%, option to join SchoolsFirst Federal Credit Union, medical, dental, and vision benefits, events and fairs (before COVID), discount at the university store (5-15%), gym membership discount for faculty/staff, safe and beautiful campus, people are kind, happy students and alumni.
cons: University Advancement is hierarchical and there are no opportunities for promotion or growth. The leadership team is exclusive and does not listen or respect their staff. They are not transparent and implement changes without the input of those who are affected. Culture has declined drastically. Systems and processes are outdated and cause many inefficiencies. Exempt employees are overworked and burnt out. High turnover in the department. Employees are required to pay to park on campus.

job_title: Administrative Coordinator in Los Angeles, CA
pros: It's a beautiful campus and the people are (mostly) an absolute joy to work with. The health benefits are good and the paid time off during the holidays is particularly nice.  Would be a great job for someone just out of college or for someone who hasn't worked in an office or higher education setting.
cons: There are major communication issues between departments and business offices on campus and many archaic bureaucratic procedures and practices that could be streamlined. This can make it very difficult to get anything done. There is little to no room for advancement within departments and the annual merit increases are almost laughable with no possibility of overtime. Because of this, there ends up being a lot of turnover of good people that can't afford to stay, even if they would like to.  Tuition remission is part of the benefits package, but there are taxes charged on the cost of tuition, often putting classes out of reach for many employees.  There is a wonderful Children's Center on campus, but again the cost and limited slots put this service out of reach for much of the part time faculty and the staff that are not a part of the upper administration.  Bottom line, it's a great place to work but the compensation doesn't reflect the effort put in.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Los Angeles, CA

job_title: Classroom IT Support in Los Angeles, CA

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA

job_title: Fundraiser in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Mission-centric environment, colleagues are nice

job_title: Field Technician in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Good benefits, great community, and very family oriented.
cons: I do not have any cons.

job_title: Copy Editor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: the faculty is so helpful, kind, and organized!
cons: Personally, didn't experience any cons

job_title: Research Associate in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Good staff and students
Mission-driven
Beautiful location

job_title: Learning Specialist/Academic Advisor & Tutor Coordinator in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Environment, happy, benefits, colleagues, professional development
cons: salary, support, compensation, relationships, culture

job_title: Software Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Easy School Job for student.
cons: No Cons with this job.

job_title: Event Specialist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Excellent benefits, adequate pay, tuition remission if you can find the time to use it. Most people generally friendly, at least to your face. Beautiful campus, great location.
cons: Little accountability from leadership who are frequently not on the same page, improperly titled, was misled or flat-out lied to on multiple occasions. Certain departments and divisions are given more weight and leeway, and allowed to get away with much more while others clean up after them. Favorites get played a lot, especially with internal hires and promotions that perpetuate a status-quo culture despite leadership saying they are want positive changes. Entry to middle manager staff should realistically begin a 3-5 year clock when they start. Get what you need to build your resume and move on.

job_title: Office Administrative Support in Los Angeles, CA
pros: LMU understands that students have a hectic schedule outside work, and are very lenient when it comes to taking time off to complete academic work.
cons: The bureaucracy at LMU means that it is very hard to work with financial aid when there is a problem on your account, and the e-time system is inefficient. Very often the immediate supervisor has to intervene when there is a problem with being paid. Also it is sometimes months before the first payment is received (of course you will still get all your pay, but it might all arrive at once). The fact that LMU forces you to choose between direct deposit and having the money paid into your tuition means that there is less personal control over funds. It is hard to know how much money you have in your bank account unless you query your bank itself.

review_title: Overall positive, though some frustrating situations
job_title: Administrative Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Work-life balance is excellent, they really encourage you to leave on time and take breaks. Employee health and fitness benefits (like employee workout classes, access to fitness challenges) are excellent. Employees are friendly and helpful, really close-knit (especially those who have been there a while). Lots of really intelligent people. The campus is gorgeous.
cons: The senior administration can be really old-school in their thinking - remember that this is a Catholic university with Catholic values. You have to always maintain a sense of decorum and professionalism, instead of just speaking your mind. Employees now have to pay for parking, which comes out of your salary - and it's not comparable in price to other universities. You have to go through multiple steps of approval before you're able to do things. You are "encouraged" to use onsite catering for events, but that really means you're forced because they'll match whatever quote you get from another company.

job_title: in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Amount of vacation is better than at most corporations, with additional paid 7-10 days off over Christmas holidays. The 403b savings plan has generous match from the university. LMU has its own childcare center on campus. Great haven of tolerance if you are gay/lesbian, having huge numbers of openly gay/lesbian faculty and administrators, including in the management ranks and a numbers of deans.
cons: Adjunct faculty tried to unionize two years ago because of poor pay and working conditions. Staff paid poorly unless a member of the senior administration. LMU has a very macho culture and a very 1950's few of women. One example: it recently separated out coverage of abortion from its healthcare coverage so you have to pay extra for a separate policy if you want that coverage. They preach collegiality but don't ever turn your back - lots of sharp knives where ever you turn.

review_title: Great organization with a clear and great mission and values
job_title: Applications Systems Analyst in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
- Jesuit mission excels at driving forward educational goals.
- All divisions know their worth and how to obtain success.
- Location - close to Silicon Beach.
- Colleagues are friendly and learn from errors.
- Facilities and environment is beautiful and well-maintained.
cons:
- Salary is on the low end of spectrum unless you're in an executive or high educational position.
- Have to deal with lots of automobile traffic outside and around campus.
- Not well let in parts of campus at night and in early morning (e.g. gym parking lot, front gates).
- Car gates are broken or not used half of the time.

review_title: Best interest of some students takes a backseat to college politics and outdated teaching philosophies.
job_title: Assistant Instructor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Beautiful location to work out, can't go wrong with the view.   Great job with student and teacher diversity.  Class sizes not too large, making the teaching process more effective.
cons: Unfortunately with regards to some of the colleges there, the students are not being given the best education opportunities possible for the money they (their parents) pay.   Material and teaching methodologies must be updates with the changes in technologies and trends.  The schools of Communications and Film are the worst offenders at this.  Makes the job of a teacher that much harder.

review_title: Varies wildly by department, but can be a very good place to work.
job_title: Administrative Assistant in Westchester, CA
pros: The university is beautiful and couldn't be in a better location. However, having worked in two different departments, I can say that it can be a bit of a gamble. University Relations was very pleasant and profession, but perhaps dull.
cons: Having also working in the Student Housing Office, I can say that this department was overstaffed, nightmarishly inefficient, and saw employee turn-over that reflected that. There are also a few people in senior management who are far too comfortable there and resist any kind of positive change. There also doesn't seem to be a whole lot of upward mobility.

review_title: there can be plenty of red tape
job_title: Administration in Los Angeles, CA
pros: great for finishing a degree through the tuition reimbursement program. the campus is a nice atmosphere to work in, especially when school is not in session and you can roam freely without student presence. the people are great and extremely fun to work with, everyone understands the stresses that come with a new academic year or semester.
cons: many tend to expect things to have been completed yesterday and show no desire to be patient. there is a strong level of bureaucracy that can make the simplest of tasks excruciating. there are inherent conflicts of interest in the structure of management that it seems are freely accepted.

review_title: Work Study Student for School of Education
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Love working for the Doctoral section of the School of Education! The entire staff made me feel like I was part of their family and were always so nice. I was always excited to go into work!
cons: Can't think of any at the moment, everything was extremely organized and nothing was left to the ultimate last second. Good work everyone!

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great benefits, beautiful campus, strong mission, good pay for higher education work.
cons: There is a huge disconnect between the Jesuit mission of the institution and the practice of those values, particularly in daily work practices of senior administrators and staff. I have never worked in an organization that fails to acknowledge toxic leadership trends in the ways I witnessed first hand at LMU and stories from peers in other departments.

job_title: Supervisor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The Lions Den made my college experience. I was involved in a lot on campus over the four years I attended the university--greek life, ROTC, volunteer work--but I most certainly remember my time in the Den most fondly. The people are awesome and I still keep in contact with tons of old co-workers even though I live 2,000 miles away. Shifts are short, so you can fit them in between classes and you are never stuck in one place for too long. WORK HERE.
cons: Pay could always be better, but its a college work study job, so no complaints.

review_title: A place in search of its soul
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
So here's the deal: You don't work at LMU for the $$$. You work here, in my experience at least, because you connect to some or all of the mission- the education of the whole person, the encouragement of learning, the service of faith and the promotion of justice. When you have chances to connect with that mission- LMU is a magical place that almost makes you forget you're getting paid pennies on the dollar. The student body is big and diverse, but the connections I did form with a number of students is what inspired me for so much of my career at LMU.

The campus is beyond beautiful and in my experience, most of my colleagues are a joy to work with. It really has so much going for it, it's just compensation and senior leadership and the new direction they are moving the school that made it no longer a place I wanted to dedicate my research and work to.
cons: So beyond the pay, what's so bad? For starters, that whole mission of the place shrinks further and further into the background as "MarCom" takes its place as the single biggest priority of LMU. For years- LMU has had an identity crisis. The words to address it change but the problem is always the same. Years ago it was striving to be "The Georgetown of the West Coast" and now the language is making fun at being a hidden jewel. At the end of the day, when those who care little about the mission get the money and power, they work on making the place more corporate and focus on Princeton Review rankings (yippee for being #64- if you meet any higher ups just pretend to care). And so the cons of the place are really just the slow destruction of all the pros (minus that whole beautiful campus thing) that used to make LMU such an amazing place to work. That's unfortunately why I decided to go elsewhere- if you're going to work for a corporate style university, you might as well make that corporate money.

review_title: Great people, but adjuncting is adjuncting
job_title: Adjunct Lecturer in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The people I ran into in my department (it was one of the humanities) - and the few people I met outside - were all very sweet, kind, and supportive. My chair was great overall. I'll go even further and say that the students were, with very few exceptions, kind, pleasant, thoughtful people who seemed to want to make it a positive experience for everyone. There was _one section_ in which multiple students complained to my chair that I wasn't teaching well, or was being unfair, but a) I know I wasn't that great a teacher; b) the occasional "pile-on" is hard to predict and doesn't mean much; c) the unrealistic expectations of ease and comfort in learning are about par for the age group, and I don't think it was reflective of that school in particular.
cons: Everyone knows how exploitative and frustrating adjuncting is - nothing specific to LMU. Occasionally, despite the pretty liberal Jesuit atmosphere, with people of all religions (and no religion) mixing freely, the Catholic patriarchy will rear its ugly head. I believe a local bishop had them remove latex condoms from vending machines on the pretext that "a lot of people are allergic to latex." Ha. Ha. Also: Very minor, but I always found the campus a little physically sterile, like a golf course. They really don't have to mow the lawn in that dopey striped pattern. It's a good school where it counts - which is with the students and faculty.

review_title: Vast Changes Needed in Enrollment Management (specifically Financial Aid)
job_title: in Los Angeles, CA
pros: You get great paid vacations and sick days, health care and overall insurance plans are good, and the campus is beautiful
cons: Horrible management that perpetuates an apathetic (when it comes to actual work issues) and overly dramatized environment (employee to employee relations). New and creative ideas are frowned on and bureaucracy reins supreme. Disorganization, sloppiness, and lack of communication throughout senior management.

job_title: Shelving Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Flexible hours, short shifts, soothing work, great community within the work family, excellent bosses. The work is easy and the environment at the library is bright, clean, and quiet.
cons: Taxes taken out of paycheck are from home state, so if you are from a state with high income taxes and are a student at LMU, you still get those taxes taken out.

review_title: I loved the supportive supervisors and environment of welcoming at the William H. Hannon Library
job_title: Student Library Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: I loved how my supervisors always made sure I was comfortable and satisfied with the work I was given. They allowed me options for which projects I wanted to work on based on my personal interests. They were always very communicative and supportive and I felt looked after.
cons: The MyTime clock-in system could be glitchy sometimes but both payroll and my supervisors were quick to assist or clarify any issues that arose.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Being a student at Loyola Marymount University is pretty wonderful. Workload is reasonable, most professors are good, and you receive a well rounded education.
cons: Some professors can be not so ideal. Some just do not care to take time to teach subjects in ways that someone who is unfamiliar with the subject would understand.

review_title: Flexible workplace, but coworkers are extremely apathetic.
job_title: in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Nice people who never really graduated from college. Very positive work environment, with flexible work hours and graduate school benefits.
cons: Coworkers are extremely apathetic. They don't really care to do things right or go above and beyond. LMU employees are don't really care about their work.

job_title: Admission Counselor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: You can get another degree or graduate degree through tuition remission which is great. Supervisor is very approachable and flexible regarding time off.
cons: Overall salaries are not as much compared to other similar positions at other colleges, and I think it prohibits those who would be a good match for positions (ex. professors, other positions).

job_title: Senior Administrative Coordinator in Playa del Rey, CA
pros: Campus attraction, coastal beauty, spiritual growth along with benefits of continuing education while an employee. On campus lifestyle with students is awesome.
cons: Commute into campus from any direction can be brutal. Movement into most positions require an MBA or post degree. Expensive parking is also a con.

review_title: Great place to work. Low stress and kind people.
job_title: Computer Support Technician in Los Angeles, CA
pros: My department support their employees continuing education by providing certification paths. And paying for training and tests. About 16 paid holidays off per year. Retirement 403b. Job security and a low stress (most of the time) work environment. The new President is amazing.
cons: Salary about $10,000 - $20,000 less than at non-government institutions and we have to pay for parking on campus but at least that means there's more parking.

job_title: OSVPSA Student Worker in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Amazing management and uplifting team to work with. They're really dedicated to your growth as an individual and trust you with responsibility that gives you an edge for any future job you may apply to.
cons: Nothing really negative. The training was great, the people are fantastic, and you get to drive a golf cart. What more could you ask for?

review_title: Enjoyed the environment and the people
job_title: Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
The campus is fantastic
The culture of service is very strong
Working with students is great
I will have friends for life from this job
Job flexibility
Good benefits (especially if your kids are in college)
cons:
Limited career paths
They pay less because they are "education"
HR makes it very hard to give promotions to all levels
The bureaucracy is very thick and makes it hard to get things done, even if they make sense and would benefit the organization

job_title: Library Reference Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Worked as a reference assistant at LMU's Hannon Library during night and weekend hours. Competent and well-organized staff. The patrons are polite and easy going. The library is gorgeous and provides a lot of great free resources to students, staff, faculty, and the general public.
cons: The night shifts can be a little boring because there are less patrons and things get a little slow. However, it's a great opportunity to do homework or read.

job_title: Administrative Coordinator in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Tuition remission only IF you qualify.
cons: Hold you back if you don’t have a college degree. Tuition remission only allows up to 2 classes a semester if you’re supervisor approves you to take the time off. Only move up if your administrator friend creates a new position for you. Where are the LMU values instilled?

job_title: Research Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: I really liked working at LMU as a research assistant. The hours were flexible and I learned a lot. I recommend it to all students looking to work and still balance classes.
cons: I wish students would be compensated more. I don't think we get enough per semester.

review_title: Great Place to Work as Student
job_title: Conferences and Events Assistant At WHH Library in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Very accomodating to class schedule and other student needs (final exams). Great environment to be around. Librarians and other staff are helpful and friendly and want to see you succeed.
cons: If there is such a thing as spending too much time at the library, working here on top of studying here certainly means that a lot of your time will be spent here.

job_title: Admissions Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: You get a lot of flexibility with your schedule and the work you do is not draining. You also get many opportunities to participate in recruiting events like Open House.
cons: There's little room for student workers to be promoted. You won't get much management experience out of this job.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: learn a lot, faculty and staff that work in office are truly there for you both for personal things as well as class/professional things
cons: since it was just a student job the hours were a little sparse as they try to give as many students employment opportunities.  also low pay, but cant really complain as its just a student job

review_title: It's a wonderful place to work at, aside from the beautiful campus, people for the most part, are a pleasure to work wit
job_title: Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: the location, the people and the salary it pretty good.
cons: HR could use some spine to support their staff and not just senior management.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Lots of freedom and ability to build on your own skills. 
Great counselors to work with.
They know your studies come first, but they treat you like a real employee not a student.
Many events to participate in (Parents Weekend, Open House, etc) for extra hours
cons: You may not always get the same desk every day, so you can't leave things behind.

job_title: Event Scheduling Coordinator in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great opportunities to network with working professionals and LMU faculty/staff, gratuitous time to do personal work, encouraged to put forth event ideas which are often put assigned resources and put into action
cons: Office/Front desk manager often gives you tedious clerical or office maintenance work, management inflexible

job_title: Graduate Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Paid well, benefits, people get to know you really well and they are invested in your success.
cons: Small teams, small offices, but lots to do. Be prepared to be responsible for a lot of projects, even on a part time basis.

job_title: Research Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Wonderful environment, the students are good to be around and keep the place from becoming mundane. Also happens to be really pretty.
cons: Dealing with some of the politics between departments can be tiresome as each is a separate entity and only responds to people of higher authority.

review_title: LMU has a great offering of graduate assistantship opportunities for MBA students
job_title: Graduate Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: All MBA students at LMU have the option to work part-time on campus as graduate assistants, earning a competitive hourly wage as they pursue their business degree.
cons: Most graduate assistants often handle administrative tasks, not being involved in the department's decision-making process.

job_title: Senior Administrative Coordinator in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Job security, location, campus environment, Jesuit tradition, nice Christmas parties, feeling of purpose.
cons: Pay is abysmal and tuition remission for the MBA Program was recently rescinded without any notice

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great benefits, excellent commute, wonderful colleagues, overall strong university mission
cons: Poor top-down communication, hierarchical structure can make it difficult during project work (respect is given by title, not by ability or work being done)

review_title: Good place to work for, questionable student acceptance
job_title: Adjunct Professor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Friendly environment, great events and community.
cons: Seems like more and more applicants are getting in because of wealth and not by merit. Some students could barely right legible sentences and this is college!

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Flexible work schedule for students, great people to work with, and exposure to a lot of different parts of the university.
cons: The work wasn't all that glamorous and the environment is pretty quiet which can mean some really dull days.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Benefits (especially the tuition remission), training, professional development, great values, networking opportunities, and a BEAUTIFUL campus to work at
cons: Little opportunities for growth for entry level employees unless you are willing to work here 10+ years

job_title: Student–Biochemistry in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The ability to learn as well as socialize with people
cons:
Homework and projects

This is not to say that I didnt appreciate the value of homework and projects, but as a biochemistry major, they would take away from the more fun aspects of college.

job_title: Resident Advisor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The best reason to be a RA is to have your living expenses paid. Students are fun to be around.
cons: If you're a busy student that does not know how to handle their academics and do multiple other extra curricular at the same time,  then this job will be overwhelming.

job_title: Office Assistant in Burr Ridge, IL
pros: Great environment. Beautiful campus and encouraging workplace. The location is the best part. LMU sits on top of a bluff overlooking Los Angeles.
cons: Not much room for growth. Some days are sluggish due to cold calling obligations and filing papers.

job_title: MIS Tutor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Staff and supervisors were very friendly and accommodating. Worked flexible hours.
cons: This position did seem a bit underpaid, however, the hours were drop in, so I did not tutor every session.

review_title: Great Students. Leadership has major room for improvement.

cons: LMU is working to reduce reliance on part-time faculty and I hope this area continues to improve.

job_title: Student Worker

review_title: Benefits do not make low pay worth wild
job_title: Information Technology Asset Management in Los Angeles, CA

review_title: Great place to work if you are serious and want to advance

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Playa Vista, CA

review_title: They care but could try harder

review_title: Great and Supportive Place to Work!

review_title: Wonderful place to work while completing your degree

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Los Angeles, CA

review_title: Great Job for a Busy Student
job_title: University Relations Office Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
